content.description: Begins as a two hand sit start. Crux is moving from the start to the next hold. Finishes with a mantle to the top.
Crux begins in the very beginning as a move from a sit start to the first hold on the right.
content.location: It is located on north side of the boulder. Second problem west of the stream, right next to problem OCLV.

climbs.name: Is That a Frog in Your Pocket?

content.description:
This is the obvious traverse that traverses, right-to-left, the most popular section of the Bridge Boulder, starting with a fingertip traverse, to a wide stem, to a low, juggy sequence, then battle across a bulge to finish at a no-hands rest on the corner left of OCLV.

5 to 7 moves total...fun, fun, FUN.
content.protection: no pad, no spotter necessary...but you must avoid the occasional frog that's basking in the sun
content.location:
Is That a Frog in Your Pocket?

starts just left of the notched "descent log"

content.description: Sit start with poor feet, improves later on, long reach to finishing move
content.location: Shares the same line with Bane, alternate start

content.description: crux mantle move, take care to not slip off
content.location: near the fallen tree, the corner area of the boulder

content.description: Sit start, left hand undercling, right hand on chalked up hold, first move crux, everything is a breeze afterwards
content.location: On the side directly opposite the stream.

content.description: Starts as a two hand sit start. As with many of the problems near it, the crux is in the beginning. The first move is a right hand bump to a small crimp and then followed by a left hand move to a small crimp. First moves are difficult due to the poor foot holds. The rest of the moves are on small crimps before bumping up to a ledge with the left hand.
content.location: The problem actually starts in the middle of Deadshot and incorporates the right start hold. It finishes to the right.
